awd_titl_txt: Research Catalyst: Environmental Quality Assurance using Ion Mobility Spectrometry
awd_abstract_narration:
Research Catalyst projects provide support for Historically Black Colleges and Universities to work towards establishing research capacity of faculty to strengthen science, technology, engineering and mathematics undergraduate education and research. It is expected that the award will further the faculty member's research capability, improve research and teaching at the institution, and involve undergraduate students in research experiences. The project at Winston Salem State University will investigate novel approaches to ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) when coupled with a membrane sampler for the separation, detection and identification of different classes of compounds in complex matrices. This work will provide research opportunities for undergraduate chemistry majors, while preparing them for careers in STEM.

The goal of this project is to utilize a novel sample introduction sampler system (SIS) as a single unit using polydimethylsilicone (PDMS) membranes and nanoparticle materials. This will allow sampling, isolation, pre-concentration, separation, and desorption of key environmental pollutants in a single step. The uniqueness of this study is the use of temperature programming similar to a gas chromatography oven, to analyze solid, liquid, and gas samples. Interfacing the unit to an ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) will allow the detection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) and semi-volatile organic compounds (semi-VOCs) of extreme environmental concern. This project has the potential to develop a sampling and sample introduction approach that requires little or no preparation and use of less or no solvent, is not labor intensive, and has greater analytical reliability. The long-term goal is to use this method for collecting samples in indoor buildings and sites suspected to have been exposed to contaminants and for analyzing water contaminated with VOCs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.inst_street_address: 601 S MARTIN LUTHER KING JR DR

perf_inst.perf_str_addr: 601 S. Martin Luther King Jr. Dr

por.por_cntn:
Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) are emitted as gases from certain solids and liquids. They include various chemicals, some of which may have short- and long-term adverse health effects. The concentrations of these chemicals are consistently higher indoors than outdoors. The EPA has recently reported that occupants of buildings can be exposed to indoor VOCs up to five times higher than outdoor levels. Moreover, because most people spend 75% of their time indoors, as opposed to outdoors, exposure to these airborne toxins is ongoing and repetitive. In this investigation, we have developed a sample introduction sampler (SIS) made of membranes for interfacing with an ion mobility spectrometry (IMS) to analyze volatile organic compounds (VOCs) in water, air, and soil samples. The SIS can perform isothermal and temperature programming to release VOCs into the IMS. VOCs are pollutants commonly found in our environment. The need to study VOCs is because several symptoms and long-term health effects are associated with exposure to these compounds. The long-term goal we anticipate with this approach is to collect samples in indoor buildings and sites suspected to have been exposed to contaminants and to analyze water contaminated with VOCs.

Our project's primary goal was to build a sample introduction device as a single unit to address challenging environmental problems regarding the detection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs). We want this device to detect solid, liquid, and gaseous VOCs with a suitable instrumentation.

Even though the project is still continuing, we are reporting on the outcomes achieved at the time of closing this project. We report on the following results.

1. The project successfully developed a LabView code to control the heating profile of the SIS.

2. The SIS was interfaced to suitable instrumentations and tested with key VOCs.

3. We have developed new knowledge for extracting VOCs from condensed phases. The SIS can be interfaced with several separation-type instruments.

4. Three peer-reviewed publications resulted from this project. As the project will continue beyond the award period, more publications will result.

5. Several minority undergraduate students had the opportunity to be trained in research during the lifecycle of the award. Some of these students presented their findings at national meetings and won awards. One student presented a poster at the 2020 Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students: The Virtual Experience, November 9-13, 2020, and won a chemistry award. Another student gave a presentation at our local section of the Central North Carolina American Chemical Society Poster Vendor Night on April 28, 2021. Another student presented at the NSF-sponsored NOBCChE Collaborative Annual Conference and Poster Competition in 2021 and won the second place award for undergraduate students.

6. Dr. Kanu, the PI of this award, presented his research at several national meetings during the lifecycle of the award. He also gave two invited research presentations and was invided to Chair/Moderate several specialized sessions at national meetings.

7. Dr. Kanu peer-reviewed scientific articles for several scientific journals and served on two review panels for the National Science Foundation.

 

This project will continue well beyond the closing of this award. We gratefully acknowledge the initial support from the National Science Foundation (award # 1900124) that kickstart this project.


Last Modified: 07/25/2022
Modified by: A Bakarr Kanu
